sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; helps you monitor the system log files for messages that interest you, alerting you when certain messages occur. You can define filters to control which messages are displayed on screen, and which ones display alerts.

The system log files are written by a syslog server (available in all Linux distributions and UNIX variants). Syslog can be configured to forward messages to other computers; by configuring syslog appropriately &app; can monitor several computers at once.

sect2.title: Configuring Syslog
sect2.para: Before running &app; for the first time you will need to create a named pipe (otherwise known as a FIFO) for it to monitor. The default path is ~/.bandsaw.fifo, but you may change it to anything you wish. Type the following at the command line and press Return:

Now you need to configure your syslog server accordingly. The configuration commands vary between different servers (refer to your server's documentation for full details), but here is an example for sysklogd. It specifies that all messages of priority notice and higher should be written to &app;'s FIFO.
Append the configuration to the syslog.conf file and restart the syslog server. More flexible configurations are possible; it can pay to become familiar with the format of the configuration file.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: The first time you start &app; you will be asked to specify the location to the named pipe that syslog writes to (see ). You may accept the default (~/.bandsaw.fifo) or specify another path.

note.para: If the path that you specify does not exist, or is not readable by your user account, you will not be able to proceed until you have corrected the problem.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, and log message view.

sect2.para: The main area of the &app; window is called the message view. It displays the messages that match the filters you define. New messages are added to the bottom of the message view as they arrive from syslog. If the maximum number of messages is reached the oldest messages will be automatically removed from the top of the view as new ones are added to the bottom.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para:
For each log message that is received from syslog, &app; checks whether or not it should:
Ignore the message
Show the message in the message view
Show the message in the message view and display an alert dialog
The default filter will cause all messages to be shown in the message view. You may control the behaviour by configuring new filters.

sect2.title: Managing the Message View
sect2.para: Log messages are added to the message view as they arrive from syslog.

listitem.para:
To remove all the messages from the message view, choose
Edit Clear .

To remove individual messages select them with the mouse or cursor keys and choose
Delete
Edit Delete Selected .

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window, with Edit menu selected for removing messages from the view.

tip.para:
You can quickly select a continous group of messages by left clicking on the first message in the group, scrolling down, holding down the Shift key and left clicking on the last message in the group.
You may also navigate and select messages with the Home, End and cursor keys, in combination with the Shift key.

sect2.title: Alert Dialogs
sect2.para: When an incoming message matches a filter that has been configured to raise an alert &app; will display an alert dialog.

textobject.phrase: Shows a &app; alert dialog, including the log message text, the host where the messages was generated, and options to ignore forthcoming alerts.

listitem.para:
The name of the filter that matched the message
— "Error" in this example.

The name of the host that created the message
— "hoopoo" in this example.

The text of the log message
— "ERROR: Something has gone wrong!" above.

sect2.para: Click the OK button to dismiss the alert.
The dialog also provides the option to Ignore alerts for a configurable number of minutes. This feature allows you to work freely despite heavy log traffic.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, choose
Edit Preferences . The Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: Use this setting to modify the path to the named pipe (or FIFO) that is being written to by your syslog server. The FIFO must exist, and be accessible by the user account that is running &app;.
Use this spin button to control the maximum number of log messages that can be kept in the message view. The larger the number the greater the resources required.

sect2.title: Filters

listitem.para: A name — used to identify the filter in the alert and Preferences dialogs.
A pattern — a regular expression, used to determine whether a message matches the filter.
Whether or not it should raise alerts.

sect2.para: &app; processes incoming messages by comparing them to the filters that you define, in the order that they appear in the Preferences dialog. If a message matches a filter no further processing will be carried out for that message.

tip.para: Filters that raise alerts should come before filters that don't.

caution.para: If you remove all your filters then &app; will never display any log messages.

listitem.para: To create a new filter click the Add button and complete the Add Filter dialog (see ).

To edit an existing filter select it in the list and click the Edit button. Modify the fields in the Edit Filter dialog (see ). You may also display the Edit Filter dialog by double clicking on the name of a filter.
To remove a filter select it and click the Remove button.
To change the order of the filters select them and click the Up and Down buttons.

sect3.title: Adding and Editing Filters
sect3.para: The Add Filter and Edit Filter dialogs contain the same settings, and differ only in name.

textobject.phrase: Shows the Add Filter Dialog, prompting for filter name, pattern and whether the filter should raise an alert.

listitem.para: The name identifies the filter in the alert and Preferences dialogs. It is compulsory.

The pattern defines the filter. It is a Perl 5 compatible regular expression used to test each log message. You do not need to understand regular expressions in order to use &app;; a simple text string is a valid regular expression.
When writing regular expressions for &app; note that they are case sensitive. Examples of suitable regular expressions include:
Error — matches the word "Error", occurring anywhere in the message.
[5-9]\d+\.\dM$ — matches two or more digits (the first of which must be between 5 and 9 inclusive), followed by a full stop, a single digit and the letter M, occurring at the end of the message.
More information on writing regular expressions is available online.

tip.para: If you need to create a filter that matches all messages set the pattern to . (a single full stop). This is the same pattern as the default filter (Everything).

listitem.para: Select Raise alerts if you would like messages that match the filter to be displayed immediately in an alert dialog. Such messages will also be displayed in the message view.
